Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Linking behavioral development to neural plasticity in the medial amygdala
Award.AbstractNarration: Puberty is a phase of life marked by dramatic behavioral change. During puberty, the reproductive axis matures causing gonadal steroid levels to rise well beyond what is normally seen in adulthood. Because of the profound emotional, cognitive, and social changes that occur during puberty, gonadal hormones must profoundly affect brain connectivity and function. What that impact is, however, is largely unknown. In this project, behavioral observation, electrophysiology, and neuropharmacology in rats will be used to identify the neural mechanisms that underlie the pubertal emergence of a discrete behavioral disposition: The attraction to the odors of the opposite sex. It is expected that testosterone will cause a specific excitatory synaptic connection within a brain region termed the amygdala to undergo long-term potentiation, i.e., an increase in synaptic efficacy. The potential impact of this work will be to identify the causal mechanisms that underlie the emergence of a discrete behavior, which has never before been accomplished in mammals or during puberty. The Data Management Plan involves the use of an electronic laboratory notebook, managed by LabArchives LLC, which permits the permanent off-site storage of all records, regardless of their format. Upon publication of the results, all data produced in conjunction with this project will be available to the public. To maximize the broader impacts of this work, teaching will be integrated with research by developing a course on Developmental Behavioral Neuroscience, comparing the efficacy of two teaching methods, and submitting our findings to a science education journal. Finally, the PIs will participate in the NET/Work program, which is a 2-year paid internship for talented undergraduates that enable them to gain hands-on research experience in University laboratories. POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to identify the processes involved in the emergence of opposite sex attraction during puberty. We focused on the medial nucleus of the amygdala (MeA) because considerable evidence points to it as a key structure in the brain that mediates social behavior, particularly opposite sex attraction. Over the course of the award, we developed two lines of research: electrophysiological recordings from MeA neurons in male Syrian hamsters undergoing puberty, and neural interventionist experiments designed to disrupt the emergence of puberty in male Syrian hamsters. The first line of research was designed to ask first, what is the impact of testosterone (T, the principal hormone of the testes) on synaptic transmission between MeA neurons. To address this, we castrated pre-pubertal male hamsters and implanted half of them with capsules containing T or nothing. After 30 days, we then prepared brain slices containing the MeA from these hamsters and made whole-cell voltage clamp recordings from MeA neurons. Action potential-evoked and spontaneous excitatory synaptic currents (EPSCs) were recorded in the MeA neurons. We then applied the sodium channel blocker tetrodotoxin (TTX) to block action potential driven currents and recorded miniature EPSCs. We aimed to record from 20 neurons from each group, T-treated and blank-capsule treated hamsters. Our preliminary results were supportive of our hypothesis, which was that EPSCs from T treated hamsters would be larger and that the frequency of miniature EPSCs would be greater. 

The second line of research asked whether neural cell adhesion molecule (NCAM) was involved in the pubertal emergence of attraction to the odors of estrous female hamsters. We first identified when male hamsters develop opposite sex attraction by repeatedly exposing prepubertal hamsters to an odor preference test. In the test, male hamsters could investigate the odors of clean or soiled bedding from estrous females. A camera overhead + tracking software recorded the duration of time spent in the vicinity of each stimulus type. We found that around postnatal day 42 male hamsters come to prefer to investigate female odors. In parallel studies we tracked the immunohistochemical expression of NCAM in the MeA, and found that it peaked around P42. This led us to ask whether NCAM in the MeA was involved in the emergence of odor preference.

We used two approaches to test our hypothesis about NCAM. The first was to inject an enzyme, neuraminidase, to dissolve MeA NCAM into prepubertal hamsters. We reasoned that if NCAM was involved, then the enzyme would forstall the emergence of attraction as compared to hamsters injected with saline control. Second, we injected a monoclonal antibody specific to NCAM into the MeA, in an attempt to functionally block the actions of NCAM. 

Both of these approaches were successful: We found that blockade or dissolution of NCAM in the MeA prior to P42 prevented male hamsters from preferring the odors of estrous females at the appropriate time. These studies were ultimately reported in the journal Hormones and Behavior.

The broader impact of these studies is based on their effort to identify the mechanisms involved in the development of sex-typical behavior, focusing on molecular mechanisms. They cast new light on a molecule, NCAM, whose role has been mostly restricted to embryonic development. Future studies, if they were to be conducted, would seek to identify how NCAM is involved in the emergence of this sex-typical behavior.
